name: Soup Kitchen Cafe

attributes.Ambience: {'touristy': False, 'hipster': True, 'romantic': False, 'divey': False, 'intimate': None, 'trendy': None, 'upscale': False, 'classy': False, 'casual': True}
attributes.GoodForMeal: {'dessert': False, 'latenight': False, 'lunch': True, 'dinner': False, 'brunch': True, 'breakfast': True}

categories: Food, Sandwiches, American (New), Cafes, Soup, Restaurants
llm_reasoning: 82% - Repeated mentions of coffee drinks and cafe atmosphere across reviews, aligning with the listed Cafes category.

text: I'd like to give Soup Kitchen Cafe a five-star review, because it's got great food and a hospitable and hip interior. The crabcake sandwich, tomato basil soup, and pulled pork are consistent winners. The downer is that after several visits over a period of months, it's become apparent that the service ranges from barely acceptable to really poor. It's not uncommon to see just two servers trying to handle a full dining section, the coffee bar, the drinks bar, and the register, which means that table visits are rare,  water glasses sit empty, and patrons wait to be seated even with empty tables. And a few weeks ago, we tried to avoid those problems by ordering their food for take-out catering for a small party, but after ten-odd phone calls, many of which went unanswered during business hours or answered and then not followed up on, we just gave up and ordered a Primo's tray. Come on, Soup Kitchen, you can do better.

You can tell the owner of the Soup Kitchen isn't cut from the cloth as some industry folk without even stepping into his shop. A trip to the web site isn't full of detours lauding their commitment to fresh produce, or a 30 second flash intro of iStock photos of Italy before an unsolicited .mp3 crackles through your speakers to fight for audio space with your Pandora station. No, SK differs greatly from the .pdf menu crowd. Their .com leads only to their menu, hours, and location. Shocking, isn't it? If only the Starrs and Garces could follow this lead, instead of doing their best impression of this: http://lobsterdonut.com/restaurant-excited-to-unveil-hassle-filled-web-site/

Inside the physical domain, nothing outperforms the meatloaf sandwich with bacon ($8.50), served on a fantastic baguette. There's not a super special recipe behind the meatloaf, it's just moist and done perfect. The supporting cast of aged white cheddar & tomato-thyme mayo deliver the warm and creamy flavor.

Pickled green tomatoes hide under covers of fontina, munster, and swiss ($6) and the grilled cheese is bookended by two great pieces of sourdough bread. The tomato's preserve treatment provides a smoother, less briney taste than traditional pickles while still serving a familiar acidic kick. Get it with soup and you'll be happy.

The pulled pork sandwich ($8.50) is fine, but not special. The nuance I think they're going for by employing apple/red cabbage and jalapeno aioli is mostly wiped out by the suffocating heat of jalapeno seeds. Also, each sandwich carries a small tote of chickpea salad on its side. A gentle squeeze of lemon gives it a fresh, light taste without any puckering acridness. 

An odd issue, though, is the smell. Even if you don't take a to-go bag you're still bringing home the kitchen's handiwork on your clothes due to the poor ventilation. It's a mild annoyance to wear your lunch on your shirt when you haven't even spilt anything, but not enough to bypass Soup Kitchen completely.

I stopped by this place around 5pm on a Monday afternoon; I had checked out the menu online and was craving some pulled pork. The place is within walking distance, which is nice, and when I arrived the place was empty. There were literally 2 people working, some flies, and a ton of empty seats. Nothing wrong with that, however, and I fully understand it being dead for the time and day of the week. 

My first and only complaint is that I still don't understand how they want you to operate when you are there. There is a sign that says to have a seat wherever you'd like, so I did. I waited for someone to come take my order, but no one seemed interested. I assumed that maybe you were to order at the counter, despite there being no "order here" signs. When I did order at the counter they looked at me like I was doing it wrong...I'm still not sure if they come to you to order or not. 

The food was great, decently priced, and a reasonable portion. The pulled pork was delish and surprisingly spicy. I love spicy foods, but I could see someone with sensitivity to spice being caught off guard by this one. The sandwich came with a side of chick pea salad which was surprisingly good. My only complaint with the sandwich is that I didn't really see or taste and BBQ sauce on it. This seems to be a trend now days, and I'm not particularly fond of it. When I eat a pulled pork sandwich I expect that sucker swimming in delicious BBQ sauce. Even so, it was scrumptious and hit the spot. The other confusing part was whether or not I was supposed to bring my dishes to them after I'm done eating. I just don't get the procedure they are going for...perhaps I'm just over thinking it. Despite being mildly confused, I will definitely give them another shot.

Wowza! Very seldom does a simple lunch leave me beaming for the rest of the day. Like a first kiss, it was playing over and over again in my head. Dramatic, but true. Soup Kitchen Cafe is my new favorite lunch spot, with ample parking to boot.

Soups and new dishes are listed on chalkboards, neatly stenciled with colored chalk. The menu is available at the front counter.

Food: A carefully thought out menu, and the price is right! You can get half a sandwich and cup of soup for $8.50; I got the spicy watermelon gazpacho, and it uh-mazing! Chilled and refreshing. Served with drizzled olive oil and garnished with dill. There was just enough heat (spice) to leave a subtle, smoldering burn in the back of your throat. The slight, sweet watermelon notes balanced well with it's tomato base, and was absolutely delectable; I couldn't stop eating it.

I got the homemade meatloaf sandwich (Smoked bacon, aged white cheddar, and tomato-thyme mayo on a baguette), a true gazpacho sidekick; I've added a photo of this beaut for visual aid. Holy shnikeys! The bread was fresh and soft, yet still substantial. The meatloaf was moist and filled the bread to the edges; all the flavors worked in a perfect symphony to yield perhaps, the perfect sandwich. I really admire their attention to detail and delicately balanced flavors.

Breakfast sandwiches look great. Sides look delicious and range from $2-4. I have my eye on the mac n' cheese (aged chedder and gruyere).

Their Cucumber Lemonade is THE BOMB!! So delicious and refreshing! No soda fountains here; awesome! They offer yummy coffee/iced coffee and also a vanilla chai milkshake that I will surely try at a later date.

Decor: modern, hipster, trendy, charming are all ways to describe this place. Teal and brown walls, modern pieces, local hipster art, Motobecane (1-cylinder) motorcycle which oddly, doesn't look out of place...it's a really nice area to chill out. Couches and comfy chairs are also readily available for your buns.

Super Plus: The sincerely polite manager/server (owner maybe?) personally came to our table to apologize for some bothersome flies; he explained that hurricane Irene had taken out their AC a few days previous and they had to have the doors open for a couple days. Their service is unmatched in my book.

Will I go back? You bet your sweet a** I will! Already anxiously waiting my next visit.

*You can call ahead and order.

**I also overheard them saying that they will be doing dinner soon. Can't wait to see what tasty morsels they'll be whipping up for that!

I am writing this because I care about you, Soup Kitchen. The food is always good here and it's the one reason I keep coming back. But please, I beg of you, get rid of your entire front of house staff (minus the lovely girl with the long dark hair -- she is the only one that can efficiently do her job). This is based on several times I have been here and my patience is beginning to wear thin. I never even write Yelp reviews and it's gotten SO bad, I just had to let you know...The servers are inattentive (I waited 12 minutes for anyone to even acknowledge we wanted our order taken), they never refill our waters (I ALWAYS have to ask and ask... and ask...), they never get the order correct (any time there is a modification or god forbid, dressing on the side... it's wrong)... they never bring the soup out on time (since when did we finish a meal with soup?)... they're just all around... bad. Get a manager in there to train or a head server to whip them into shape -- even just teach them what it takes to have good service and hustle.  Your food is saving your restaurant and I've been coming here for a while -- the place looks great too. Don't let it go down in flames because of a couple bad eggs. Not everyone is meant to be in the service industry... get them out of there and give your customers what we deserve, people who know what they're doing.

Such a cute little hidden gem. Tasty soups and salads are all very thoughtfully made. I am normally not a big sandwich person unless it's a banh mi as I feel a little wasteful going out to buy something I can whip up at home. We wanted to try something new so BF and I both ordered our own half soup and salad. The tomato basil soup was creamy and full of fresh basil. The soup of the day with chicken and rice was stellar (I ended up trading the BF for this because I was so obsessed). 

My beet goat cheese sandwich was very very tasty. Awesome balance of fresh arugula and savory ingredients. I have a thing against toasted whole grain bread that scratches up my sensitive gums though so I probably won't get this again. 

BF's burrata BLT was to die for.. soo good. Extremely awesome marriage of ingredients and the bread was perfectly toasted. Was tempted to "trade" the BF for this too but I was feeling generous and settled for a few stolen bites instead ;)

Waitress forgot our cucumber lemonade and was a bit slow having to work the front restaurant by herself while picking up the phone etc so nothing personal there, and we were super full and satisfied anyway. They serve fresh reAnimator coffee and play awesome coachella music. Would definitely try this place again!

I went to this Cafe with my son for lunch. 
It is totally awesome. It is totally comfort filling food. 

We obviously went with a soup, since they are supposed to be one of the best in Philly at soup. Both of us had Tomato Basil. 
It is unlike any soup I have had before. It was delicious. Clearly it is home made as it had little chunks in it. You had sweetness from the tomato and basil flavor. I swear a cheese flavor in it as well. 
We both did soup and a sandwich and I thought the bowl would be small, it was not. At first I thought they must have something wrong, but they did not. 
I also had a cucumber lemonade that was outstanding. You could taste both and it fit with the wholesome meal. 
Now on to the sandwich portion of the meal. My son went the obvious grilled cheese. When he pulled the halved sandwich apart the cheese just strung out in a large quantity. This was to my sons absolute glee, he gained a large smile at seeing the stringy cheese. They are generous with the cheese, I swear it was a half inch of the goodness between the bread. I had a taste of the grilled cheese, I ate half to be exact. It was delicious. The bread was fabulous and likely home made. 
My sandwich I had a half meatball sandwich. It was delicious and my only wish was that I ordered a whole sandwich and not a half. It was earthy and homey, a true comfort type of food. 
I really loved the place and want to go back. The place is spacious and bright. The walls could use some cleaning, but that is about it. 
To finish it off, my son really wanted dessert and we got the bill before they asked. So we ordered a cookie on the way out as we paid at the cashier. I'm not sure she charged us for it. When I pointed it out, the hostess waved us on and said it is not a big deal. She thought she had.  I guess chalk that up to my super cute son.

I've known about Soup Kitchen being open for a while now, and I drive by it every day on my way to work. Today my husband and I finally made it out, and it was DE.LISH!

We went around noon, and it was difficult for me to decide if I wanted to go the breakfast or the lunch route...so I took a different path: dessert! I got the brownie batter waffle, which is exactly what it sounds like, served with vanilla ice cream, whipped cream, and fudge. It was mind blowing. Seriously. The waffle was so soft and not at all like I imagined the texture to be. I thought it'd be a lot "heavier" but it really wasn't. This dish could get you into trouble...

My husband went the lunch route. He got the soup and "half" a sandwich. The soup was sausage and bean, which was perfectly seasoned and had just the right amount of heat to it. He ordered the meatloaf sandwich, and as soon as he saw it he said, "THAT'S A HALF A SANDWICH!?" It was definitely enough to fill you up. The sandwich came with cheese and bacon, but the real highlight was, of course, the meatloaf. It was soooo juicy and definitely not like your mother's meatloaf.

We also had to get a side of macaroni and cheese, because I read on here that it was a winner. Whoever wrote that review was right. The gruyere cheese was the perfect choice - and I like that they're not shy with the pepper.

Another highlight: the cucumber lemonade. It takes a lot of sweat to churn out one of these bad boys, but I thank the staff for doing so, because it was SUPER refreshing. Don't worry, the lemon doesn't get lost with the cucumber, it only gets enhanced. I'm going to have to get that drink again.

Things I want to try: their house breakfast sandwich. I can't remember exactly what's in it, but I know for certain that it includes asparagus and some type of meat that resembled prosciutto. It looked great, and I think it's served on an everything bagel (my favorite). Also: the chai milkshake. Need I say more about why I want to try that?

Anyway, this place is a gem. The inside is really comfortable and has a lot more seating than you'd expect from looking at it outside. The prices are definitely reasonable and the food is quite creative. Also, it's probably only a short walk from where you live! Check it out!!

First Things First: SOUP KITCHEN Cafe? Why are we making a play on words like this in a neighborhood suffering from poverty. The name is disgusting and in poor taste! 
We visited this place for lunch on a Friday. It was our first time. 3 stars overall. We ordered the Ham, Red bean and Kale soup, an everything bagel with cream cheese and a baguette on the side. The soup was OK at $4.50 a bowl, but nothing I would re-order, the bagel was tasty, and the baguette was good as well. Couple things that would keep me from returning...It was freezing in there...(I am not a cold person either) we both left with cold feet...please turn up the heat...Our food didn't come out together...(We got our soup then 7 minutes later got our bagel) Then our baguette didn't come till we basically didn't need it anymore because our soup was gone. Lastly, and this is hard to write...Our waitress was REALLY nice, but her hair was so filthy that it made me cringe and feel gross about the food...I get that its kind of a hipster place...but at the end of the day your serving food...and having hair that looks that dirty is a major turn off to eating customers. I really have never seen anything like it.

The food is delicious...if you're willing to wait long enough for it. My husband and I were not this time, and had to walk out after 40 minutes. He was served his glass of lemonade and water - I received nothing. An entire table of four walked out before us because they had never even been acknowledged after sitting for 20 minutes. Neither of the two waitresses noticed. It doesn't seem to matter whether they are busy or not - the food comes out consistently slow and out of order. The place isn't that big, the menu isn't that complicated - they are only open limited hours, ostensibly catering to a lunch crowd, but I don't know who can take that much time out of their busy day. Management seriously needs to get it together on speed, organization and multitasking or we will never be back.

The combination of rude staff and overpriced food ensures that I have made my last trip to Soup Kitchen. The staffs attitude is poor. I can't justify paying nearly $7 for a bagel and coffee, especially when I am ignored by the staff, and scoffed at when I mention that they raised their prices with no warning. They recently started charging an extra dollar for in-house coffee refills, which jacked my bill up. I don't know of another place that has such a policy. When I expressed my mild surprise at my heightened bill, the girl at the register gave me a reply loaded with attitude. I have consciously chosen against going here in the past because I feel queasy giving my money to such rude people, which is a bummer considering that I enjoy their food. 

I think it's worth mentioning how distasteful their name is, considering that they're at the forefront of gentrification. I have had many a friend put off by their inconsiderate name. Any diner would have a better experience walking a block or two over to Ida Mae's Bruncherie.

Never heard of this place until I was invited here for an event. The outside is kind of unassuming so I approached the establishment with apprehension not knowing what to expect from a place called "Soup Kitchen". Well it's fair to say I was pleasantly surprised. 
The interior is small but you never feel cramped. Instead I think it creates a certain intimacy between you and the "kitchen". I put kitchen in quotes because from what I could see the kitchen of the Soup Kitchen is about the size of a closet. But luckily size doesn't matter for everything because the food pumped out of that closet was delicious imo. 
Maybe a large kitchen is not needed since the menu here is not that expansive. I was able to sample pretty much everything on the menu in one dining. My favorite dishes here are the mac and cheese, meat loaf and the pulled pork sandwiches. I also had the chicken salad sandwich, which had a nice twist to it as it had something with a crouton type consistency in it , and the crab cakes. The stand out dish was certainly the pulled pork which I hear is nominated for best in philly. Topped with sliced apples the pulled pork packs a light kick courtesy of the jalapeno sauce. Apples? Jalapeno dressing? Pork? I know what you're thinking.....Trust me it works. Every bite was moist, juicy and delicious. Also i'm not sure what it means but the pork tasted very "fresh" , like "porky" but not in a gamey sense...... if that makes sense. Every element of the sandwich just clicked together   perfectly imo. 
This place is probably not on a lot of radars but it should be. I rate it a good 4 out of 5 with the only knock being the limited selection and the ikea like plastic chairs they have at the tables for two (they also have leather seats that look comfortable to be fair). The food here is excellent and the staff is nice and friendly (they let my GF select the venue playlist off an ipad). Will come again

I just left eating from here and I would have to say the service gave this place a 1 star. I walked in with my bf and the waitress immediately gave me this look like, "WTH are you doing here?" 
So we get seated and  no one takes our order for over 10 mins while they attended to everyone else. Already impatient, another waitress walks over and takes our order but doesn't write anything down. 
My order: 2 sandwiches, 1 soup and 2 coffee. Another 10 mins goes by, no coffee still. Finally flagged down the waitress and I ask her what happened to our coffee? "Oh I'm sorry, I forgot", uhhhh what? So if you're forgetful, why didn't you write down our order? 3 STRIKES, you're out!!!

This girl is lucky I have her $2 tip, never again at this place. Food is decent but not good enough to return to crappy service

Unfortunately I cannot give Soup Kitchen a rave review even though I love the food because I've experienced horrendous service at least 4 out of the 10 times I've been here. I also never feel compelled to write yelp reviews but after this morning, I feel I should. 

I came in with two friends and only waited a few minutes for a table. We were promptly greeted and brought waters but when it came to ordering the waitress took my friends food orders and proceeded to walk away. I let her know I would also like to order food. So she asks what I want and walks away as I'm ordering. She starts talking to a guy behind her she obviously knows and eventually turns back around after catching up with her buddy and proceeds to take the rest of my order. It was a build your own breakfast sandwich with avocado.

My friend mentions the waitress didn't seem to be paying close attention to the order and since I don't eat meat and the house breakfast sandwich has prosciutto on it I wanted to make sure there weren't further complications. I walk up to the counter and just reiterate which sandwich I meant as she's putting the order in the computer. She rudely assures me that "she's got it." and I sit back down. 

The food runner brings my friends their food as I sit patiently waiting for my sandwich to come out. Our waitress doesn't check on us to see if everything came out okay or tastes good or if we need anything else. 20 minutes later, my friends are nearly finished with their meals and I walk back to the counter and let her know I still haven't received my food. I return to my seat and she comes over to tell me she "forgot to put it in." The sandwich comes out after a few minutes and I eat it quickly because I was starving and we were pretty pressed for time. 20 minutes later and she hasn't come back over, We're sitting at the table with empty glasses and dirty plates and money on the table. My friend asks for the check as she walks past us and she brings it over. She didn't even take a single drink off the tab as a consolation for her mistake. 

We pay and leave a little over 15% tip. As a server and bartender, I never leave less than 20% and typically leave 30%. However when a server doesn't give me any indication that she wants my business let alone my tip, I feel there's no need to show my appreciation of her service. There was also no manager on the floor to voice my complaints to and I'm not the kind of person to ream a server over making a mistake and then showing zero regard for her customers. I'll just leave and never come back,

I walked into Soup Kitchen Cafe and was greeted right away by the extremely friendly staff. The decor is clean and simple with plants hanging in big, wide windows. Some of the tables are made out of slabs of wood, with a bar area that can accommodate about 6 people. There are nice people (and dog) watching opportunities if you're facing the two little parks across from the cafe. 

The Reanimator coffee they serve is too strong for me - I prefer La Colombe - but my husband loves it. I give them props for using a local coffee company, though. The Build-Your-Own breakfast sandwich was very hot and very delicious. Mine arrived with two fluffy eggs, melty cheese, and just ripe avocado on a brioche bun. You can also get two types of tomato, caramelized onions, or several types of meat on your sandwich, and there's the option to get it on an everything bagel.

Okay, so we were there at 10am, but felt the need to try a soup since the place is called "Soup Kitchen". We had the tomato basil, which was far superior to most tomato basil soups I've had, which are usually watery. This one was creamy, nicely spiced, and tasted like it might have been flavored with sherry or some other wine. I didn't really taste basil, but the soup was so good, it didn't bother me.

The menu is on the simple side, but the options are varied and tasty. I would love to stop in for lunch the next time I'm in Philly.

While visiting Philly, I wanted soup, so here I went! The soup was mediocre at best! The server woman with blonde hair and glasses didn't gave enough of a good impression to ever come back here. As I was placing the order I never planned or said I wanted my order to go, she just shoved this option without even asking. While I understand it's one hour away from closing and you want to go home please have the decency and courtesy to ask the customer if it's for in or to go. This action of hers just made her seem lazy, careless, and seem like she hated her job specially the way she smashed those receipts with anger in the holder spike stick bill fork. When I mentioned this to her as she brought my order all she said was "you could of told me" putting the blame back on me. I was completely confused as to why I needed to tell her it's called customer service and it's your job to ask not just assume or shoved your option you see fit or both. After mentioning this to her she gave me a horrible attitude then got a new soup and smashed my soup on the bowl full of rage. I didn't appreciate her rage going into my bowl. Then another couple came in and she did greet them and offered for in or to go at this point idk if it was inconsistency of customer service from her part and lacking customer service experience, hates her job so she needs to be reminded or just being plain B to other women! Weirdest vibe I got from was from her and the chef with semi long hair!

If I wrote a review just based on the food, it would be 5 stars. Between my husband and I we have tried almost everything on the menu and it all has been delicious. Unfortunately the terrible service has lessened our dining experience every time. We have given this place the benefit of the doubt multiple times but I think we're finally just done. Expect to wait a very long time to be seated, to be served, and to be given your check. The waitresses frequently pay no mind to the guests once seated so hopefully your food is correct and you don't want a drink refill. They have lost a couple hundred dollars of mine by now by not picking up the phone for takeout on Friday and Saturday nights. They just let it ring endlessly . Today they were unable to seat us because despite multiple tables being open, they didn't have time to clear them. I frequently wonder if the manager/owner is aware of how much business is missed by his/her waitstaff; it's unreal. The hipster waitresses would significantly benefit from a few lessons in manners, efficiency, and working as though you're at a job.

I feel bad about the 2-stars because the food here is some of the best in the city for quick, good-quality breakfast/lunch options, and I've been going here sine they opened a few years ago.  But overall the service is very inconsistent and falls into the classic trend of "hipster service", which is to say a few unprofessional, inexperienced, and utterly disinterested servers are hired and customers seem to just deal with it.

There is really only 1 bad server, and everyone else works pretty well, but the one girl with horn-rimmed glasses is the absolute worst server I've ever experienced, and how she is still employed is beyond my powers of reasoning...other than to acknowledge that the new transplants into the neighborhood are so charmed by seemingly hip, insubstantial things that they just put up with it as 'de rigur' to living there...But coming from the restaurant industry in a time where effort and ability still seemed to matter more than quirky outfits and tattoos, I can't accept it from this place anymore.  It's novelty has never charmed me.

The food is truly 5-stars, and if I were the "chef" or a cook here, I would throw a soap party to make sure that drooling moron washes the f*ck out and stops ruining everyone's experience of my hard work.

From now on it's take-out only for me from this place.

Amazingly Delicious simple  and delicious food --with a side of hipster irreverence and (uncharacteristically) particularly dismissive , fake , and aloof service --on this particular day .

Was it the fact that I was reading a magazine at the counter that put them off?

Did my please and thank you and "could I trouble you Fors" ....offend their hipster sensibilities?
(swear to god this is a thing --sometimes the ruder and colder people are to hipsters --the warmer they seem to respond in some masochistic twist of irony )

I don't understand why the service was so particularly rude to me on this day more than any others I've been there , but it was more noticeable , pointed , and by the time I left --really irritating --lack of care --than I normally receive here --and I am always nice and polite . It took me a while to get annoyed --but annoyed I was by the time I walked out the door .

Maybe they had yet to hit their groove before the lunch brunch arrived (by the time a young woman and a couple sat down beside me, the fake cheer at least seemed to have turned on )
Or perhaps the barista finally perked up because she sensed my final irritation of her under -attentive service . I'm not going to say it was egregious --but it was pretty lackluster and was echoed by the team around her.

I almost had to stir my coffee with my finger because no roll up --no biggie at all .

Needed a knife for my salad and she had gone to the basement --got up and asked another server --who didn't smile but seemed irritated I politely interrupted her .

Had to finally ask a 3rd server for a takeout container for my soup (I ended up wrapping my corner of sandwich in my napkin as she didn't offer even though I'm pretty sure she saw it because --yes --I didn't want to waste it --although of course that's hard to be sure of .

Finally , though I had my coat on and pretty much as a server who would have noticed the itch in my Days --and still had to wait politely a few minutes --before asking for my check --

She perked up after I think she sensed a bit of feeling ignored on my part and a noticeably much improved tone towards the folks who just sat down . And finally got me both a coffee cup --and a to go cup for my lemonade without my asking .

Left a more than 20% tip even though to be honest this service far from deserved it today and I will be back .

It was only when I was about to leave that they got busy lest you think it was that .

You know when you just sense a hostility from servers or a sense that they are trying not to notice you are standing at the counter waiting for a to go bag , silverware , and they don't catch your eye just so it could be plausible enough they didn't see you ? Or they need to get side work done and you aren't their table anyway ?

Nothing I could put on paper --was overtly rude /-just a strong vibe of being overlooked , ignored , and annoyed at by the staff --while they seemed to get nicer the more people came in .
I felt I went out of my way to be more polite and patient than the average customer who wasn't a server would be , but they seemed to somehow take that as permission to be more lax .
Not a good showing this time around , but the damn tomato bAsil is so freakin good and  the grilled cheese , there is no way they are keeping me out of there .

Love my usual order here (grilled cheese and tomato basil soup) tastes great but is a little on the pricy side.  Yesterday, though, I had an unpleasant experience with the woman at the register.  I placed my order ahead of time and went to pick it up and the food wasn't ready.  After some time, she called me up to the register to tell me that my sandwich was made incorrectly.  I explained that I would wait for a new sandwich and she seemed very annoyed at my decision.  She then went on to tell me that it would be another 15 minutes for just a grilled cheese.  I contemplated just getting my money back at this point but then realized I didn't want to travel some where else.  About 3 minutes went by and the same woman came over to me, practically tossed my meal down on the table and said sorry for the inconvenience while walking away and her back already towards me.  After getting back to work, which is only 1 block away, my soup was cold which could only mean that it was left out while my new grilled cheese was being made.  Probably won't be going back here based on this type of service.
